thread.title: Top End cattle station manager resigns after 20 years
thread.title_full: Top End cattle station manager resigns after 20 years

author: Daniel Fitzgerald
title: Top End cattle station manager resigns after 20 years
text:
Map: Katherine 0850 
The manager of Newry Station has resigned after 20 years working on stations across the Northern Territory and Western Australia. 
Tom Shephard has worked on properties owned by Consolidated Pastoral Company (CPC) since 2000, including managing Humbert River Station for eight years. 
Since 2010 Mr Shephard has managed CPC's Newry Station on the WA and NT border. 
Mr Shephard is well known throughout the NT and east Kimberley cattle industry for his skills as a cattleman and his work with dogs. 
Arriving in the NT in 1997, he came for six weeks of work at the Kidman Springs Research Station in the Victoria River District. 
"It went from six weeks to 20 years, but I enjoyed it, that's the main thing," Mr Shephard said. 
After a few years at Kidman Springs, Mr Shephard picked up work with CPC, training weaners with dogs at Carlton Hill Station in WA. 
Mr Shephard said he was the first to educate CPC weaners with dogs. 
"It was a hell of a learning curve because I had never worked numbers or seen numbers like they had there [at Carlton Hill Station]," he said. Photo: Tom Shephard feeds his goats for the last time before leaving Newry Station. (ABC Rural: Daniel Fitzgerald) 
After working in CPC stock camps training new staff and helping muster, Mr Shephard was promoted to manger of Humbert River Station. 
Bordered on two sides by Gregory National Park, Mr Shephard said he had liked the remoteness of the property. 
"I liked Humbert River. It was a little place tucked away from everyone," he said. 
"It was really good because I don't mind the peace and quiet. Over the wet [season] the rivers were all up so no-one would humbug you." Weather the biggest challenge 
On becoming a station manager, Mr Shephard said he liked working with other staff, but bookwork took some time to get used to. 
"It was more the bookwork side of things I had to get my head around more than anything. The staff and livestock weren't a great deal of problem," he said. 
"I don't change staff over that much. In the stock camp I had years where they have come back two or three years in a row, but generally I only turned two or three over in a camp every year, so I was lucky like that. 
"I think if you can keep people learning new skills â€¦ and you are prepared to work with them, I think it is a lot easier." 
Mr Shephard said often the biggest challenge he faced while managing stations was the weather. 
"Someone told me there is only a couple of inches [of rain] between a good and a bad manager," he said. 
"But we are lucky here [at Newry Station] because we have some sort of a wet season every year, so we have time to work with it. 
"Sometimes lighter wet seasons aren't too bad because the grass is sweeter, but then you can have a good wet season and fires can come through and change your plans again." 
Mr Shephard said his three children, two of whom were born at Humbert River Station and one at Carlton Hill Station, were lucky to grow up on the land like he did. 
"I think they are going to miss [Newry Station] more than anyone," he said. 
"[Living on the station] they do grow up in their minds a lot quicker. They know what is going on and know what should be done around the place. 
"I think some of these first year [ringers] get a bit upset with them, [when they] tell them what to do." 
While Mr Shephard is moving his family to north Queensland, he will return to do contract work for CPC, helping train new staff. 
Management of Newry Station has been taken over by Dave Young.
